You wouldn't be human if you didn't feel some anxiety going in, but you have done your part at this point.

Enjoy the beach!!!

Great info to share, Anita.

Good call on the ER, Jen. And Doug knows better than to argue with the two of you!
posts.topic: Tip to caregivers after TURB/bladder biopsies

posts.text:
Hi Anita... Perhaps many want to think those dealing with bc (or any cancer for that matter) are 'tough as shoe leather' because they just can't imagine going through it themselves. Or, maybe it is their way of telling you they admire and respect your strength and courage but don't really feel comfortable saying it directly.

That is a wonderful thing about having the forum... we don't have to act tough here. We can let the wall down and be ourselves, be vulnerable, and be honest about our fears.

{{{Hugs}}} to you and Doug...

Just wanted to send good wishes for your husband tomorrow and I hope that his surgery can take care of this situation. I know he has already been through a lot, and so have you. His case is more complicated than what most of us have experienced, so that is why you haven't gotten a lot of specific comments.

But know that we all stand with you because we DO know what it's like to stare uncertainty in the face, and how scary that feels. Blessings to you both... please let us know how things go so we can continue to cheer you on.

Hello Nancy... I am so sorry that you have received this devastating news. This is where a meeting with an oncologist and your urologist will have to determine the most effective way to treat this new development. Have they suggested further surgery, or perhaps to do chemo first? Do you feel that a second opinion is in order if you have not had an outside referral? It is always so hard to know what to do when faced with an unexpected scary turn like this.

I wish had more to offer but I've never dealt with your particular situation. I can only send wishes that you have the best possible outcome with whatever path you choose. There are others here who have gone through a chemo regimen. I hope one of them can add to this thread.

I am so sorry that your husband's diagnosis has become so advanced. It sounds like the whole ordeal has been a whirlwind since learning of his cancer only in June. Dealing with a serious illness brings many new realities into our lives, and having those people there who sincerely care about us and offer to help is truly a blessing. Thanks for your insight on graciously accepting their assistance. I, like you, have always prided myself on being independent and taking care of myself. When I went through my cancer diagnosis and surgery, my family and friends rallied around immediately. I don't know what I would have done without that. My thoughts and prayers will be with you, your husband, and your family.

Hello Karkey... Welcome to our site and I am so sorry for the circumstances that brought you here. I am very happy that you still have great love and admiration for your father in your heart despite some of his past hurtful actions. I respect that a great deal.

You pose an interesting thought as to whether he sees himself, or cancer, in the mirror. After my diagnosis, and even after my surgery cleared my body of the cancer, it took a long time before I looked in the mirror and did not see the dark word "cancer" hanging over my head at the same time.

I am fairly certain he is suffering from major depression about the state of his health, in addition to the past guilt regarding the family. That can be a big reason people pull away... they just don't feel like dealing with the emotions because it is so exhausting to do so. Sometimes the emotional pain is greater than the physical pain, and even more debilitating and isolating.

Have you considered just writing all the wonderful things you shared with us about your father in a note and mailing it to him? At least he will know you are still on his side regardless of how he sees the situation. And, you will at least have had the chance to let him know how you feel before it is too late. That will put the ball in his court as to the next move.

I do hope he will reach out to you and allow you to be there for him during this very difficult time ahead. I think your attitude shows that you are also a great daughter of a great Dad!

Helene... You are so very welcome. We are all saddened by your loss. If you start feeling overwhelmed by those dark moments, check in with us here anytime. You are forever a part of our forum family.

{{{Hugs}}}...

Catherine
This is so wonderful!!! Persistence is the key in finding the right doctor until all avenues are exhausted. I am so happy for her and her family!

I am also a fan of 5HTP. I take a night time supplement to help with sleep due to years of fibromyalgia related insomnia. Through the years, doctors have tried to get me to take antidepressants (first line of fibro treatment) and I would try them for a few days to a couple of weeks but never found any satisfactory results. I am very sensitive to any medications, so any dose of SSRI's zone me out to zombie land. That is not a good tradeoff for me since I have never felt that I met the criteria for depression.

On the other hand, I have several friends who have found great relief with antidepressants. I know they work wonders for many, but they are just not for me.

I am glad you've found something to make you feel better! Another factor I discovered from my new and wonderful primary doctor about a year ago is getting my Vit D levels up to over 60. After about a week of taking 4000 iu's daily, I was actually sleeping for a few hours at a time instead of being on my 30 minutes sleep-3 hours awake cycle. Seriously live changing!

And, I now see a counselor about once a month to help deal with my "C" concerns and worries, plus life issues in dealing with constant fibro fatigue. It has helped having an objective outlet for my anxieties. Self-care is definitely an ongoing process...

Hello Dana... just wanted to let you know I was thinking about you and your husband. I hope things are getting better for him in dealing with all that has happened and the changes in his life post-surgery. I really hope that you are taking care of yourself and are finding less stress in your daily routine.

Sending warm thoughts to both of you...
Thinking of you both on Wednesday...
I am just excited to see a major university studying and researching invasive bladder cancer. Thanks for the post!

posts.text:
I know how you feel. My urologist and surgeon left Vanderbilt last September to take the position of Head of Urology at University of Oklahoma which allowed he and his wife to return to their hometowns. I was so comfortable with him doing my followups because he knew what was done during my surgery and what to look for during my cystos.

It was a great sense of loss when I had to choose a new uro. My last check up was with my new doctor and he put me a ease right away and his background gives me high confidence in him as well.  I'm sure the same will happen for you as well.
Hello Phil... Welcome to the forum. Best of luck on your upcoming third TURBT. That sounds like a lot to go through in 18 months. Have you had BCG or any other treatments?

I ran across this topic today and searched for legitimate info as to whether there was any merit to the association. Seems there is so I thought I would post a link to this National Institute of Health study here:


	Beta-Carotene Supplements Confirmed as Harmful to Those at Risk for Lung Cancer
That would be a huge step forward if this proves successful. I so hope that Mr. Chambers has a wonderful result from this trial.
posts.topic: UM’s clinical trial for new bladder cancer drug

posts.text: Great story, Mike. Very encouraging that someday we may be able to kill the beast! (Or at least make him slink away and leave us alone.)

I saw that this morning and thought what an improvement in the process (assuming results prove out). The next day I was so dehydrated they had a hard time getting a vein to start an IV during surgery prep.

You're right, Sara Anne, it is a tough one to weigh in on. In my case, my tumor was invasive T2a and the scans are to both check for recurrence and mets, along with the cystos. It seems there is not much data to go on when it comes to adenocarcinomas, and he is being cautious which I have to say, I do find reassuring because that possibility still has me truly scared.

Dr. Cookson did say that if my next scan in October is clear, we can let up a bit as that will take us to almost the two-year mark. This is the first time I have gone 6 months between cystos.

All that said, I do worry about the radiation exposure and that article hit home because I know a lot of us here get scanned fairly often compared to the general population. What to do??? Never a clear path is there?
posts.topic: Too Much Radiation or Just Careful Followup???

posts.text:
I've had two abdominal/pelvic CT scans now in the course of my BC diagnosis and followup, with the third scheduled in October. Both times I was double scanned using the Non-Contrast/Contrast protocol which I thought was the norm.

This New York Times article specifically addresses CT scans of the chest and says too much radiation is used and it is too costly, and most of the time unnecessary. It is based on Medicare records. Just wondering if this thinking is applied to most areas of the body that are CT scanned.

Do you think this applies to us BC patients? What are your thoughts on this?


	Overuse of CT Scanning
posts.topic: Too Much Radiation or Just Careful Followup???

It is truly wonderful to see new breakthroughs in treating any type of cancer. The husband of one of my friends had a kidney removed a couple of years ago because he had a malignant tumor encapsulated inside it. This could have given him a different outcome.

I read that last week, Cynthia. Interesting stats but I was saddened to read one of the marked differences in treatment patterns cited is insurance status. While I know this is true, it hurts me to think people don't have the same options for the best care because they can't afford health insurance.
What a wonderful organization. Thanks for passing this along, Pat.

Hey Doc... I can tell this is weighing on you heavily. Sometimes circumstances are such that our help is unwanted, or even unwelcome, and we have to respect the boundaries others have set. That can be difficult when things happen to people we care about and we know they are suffering.

It sounds like you don't have a path to help your daughter-in-law, but your wife will need your support as her DIL's health deteriorates. Sometimes all we can do is just be available... and we have to find a way to be OK with that.

Don't feel bad or guilty about bowing out. You offered, I'm sure multiple times, and your help was discouraged. I do hope the projections are wrong and maybe she will decide differently about fighting her battle, but in the end, it is her decision to make.

Great idea, George! I vote for CLEAR too! Clear wrist bands would look awesome and match every outfit! Clearly a great fashion accessory!

Great snap, DieselDoc!  Had to "borrow" it...

Maybe that is all HE can do for you... do you think there would be any value in getting a referral to another specialist? I know you probably don't even want to think about starting that process over again, but give it some thought in a couple of days.

So sorry about all this...
Yeah me!!! And, hope you're feeling well today!

DD... so sorry this has come back again. 

What did your doc do when it happened before? Hope you're feeling better soon...

(And you can't be at the end of your witt... we need it around here!  )
That is VERY good news. Glad you're feeling better and hope you continue healing quickly. Maybe that was causing some of your excessive pain all along. Rest, rest, and oh yeah... REST!

Pat... At least things are moving in a forward direction with your diagnosis ruling out cellulitis plus a clean CT scan.

And let me know if you have any luck with that fat relocation you mentioned. I could use a bit of fat transference to more suitable places!

Almost fell out of my chair laughing at that "snappy" comeback, Doc! Good one!
Diesel... Hope all goes well with your upcoming surgery. Wish I had a snappy response, but I'll have to leave that to George. It's early and my "snap" hasn't kicked in yet!
Joining the chorus here to send best wishes and positive thoughts!
Thanks for sending me to bed with a good laugh. I'm definitely going to share this one!

I drink Horizon Organic milk, either 1% or 0%. I would love to know how it would fair on those tests. While they advertise that their cows are not given antibiotics or hormones, it seems that many of the named contaminants have found their way into our water supplies, thus water we drink as well as the animals. Who knows what's actually in their feed!

It seems that there is very little we can do to be "contaminant free" in today's world. I fear this will start to show up in a few years with many people having various cancers and other toxin-related illnesses in alarming numbers.

I hate to be the "sky is falling" person, but it's hard to be optimistic that this will turn around.
OMG... thank goodness you were not seriously injured! Does that have anything to do with your ruptured disc? So sorry about all that!

It would be nice if CNN used this tragic loss as a springboard to do a story about bladder cancer and its terrible toll. Awareness is the first step to early treatment when often the most benefit can be gained.

RIP Mr. Charles...

They kicked that off a couple or so weeks ago. I was bummed too. I've been reading it daily since my surgery in Feb. 2010. There are other sources of info out there, but it was nice to have it all in one place with a daily email.

OMG... I am so sorry this has happened to you. There are some truly mean and deceitful people in the world, and it is even more hurtful because this was someone you trusted.  I am so glad your insurance company worked with you, and even happier that your husband's scan came back clean.  That is definitely something to celebrate even in the midst of everything else that has gone wrong.

Has this person been charged? I hope she has to face the music and gets the appropriate punishment. Is there any way to recoup any of your money?

Please feel free to vent here anytime you need to. It is a safe haven from the storms of life... whatever they may be.

I think that is a very astute observation, Duke.  I frequent a forum for Blackberry phone enthusiasts and they are so snarky and hateful with each other.  A 'my phone can beat up your phone' or 'my Blackberry is better that your iPhone' is the constant theme. They pounce on people who innocently ask a question that may have been asked somewhere else in the forum. I mostly lurk because it does provide lots of good techie info.  It could not be more different than this wonderful site full of people who have faced hardships and are willing to share their experience for the betterment of others.

When I was diagnosed in January 2010, I was about 75% through a major home renovation (kitchen, 2 baths, master BR).  I was so determined to pick out just the right items, went to the home improvement stores almost daily, and became obsessively involved with all that stuff.

After being diagnosed and surgery, I won't say I lost interest in all that, but it no longer seemed so important that all the light fixtures coordinate, or that the new hardware be the exact shape and color. I still have a few things that have not been finished, but I'll get back to it when I get to it.

The word "cancer" just put everything into proper perspective that health and life trumps all of that.  It reset my "gratefulness" meter and now as I sit looking out my window at the spring blooms on the trees and the country landscape coming back to life, I feel more contentment than any home "upgrade" could ever deliver.
I think privacy is an illusion today. I just got another email from Chase with the same info.
